description:
Human genital-associated circular DNA virus-1 (HGCV-1) is a recently discovered virus that belongs to the family Circoviridae. It is a small, non-enveloped virus with a circular, single-stranded DNA genome.

HGCV-1 has been detected in various human genital samples, including those from individuals with sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and healthy individuals. The virus is believed to be sexually transmitted, but its exact mode of transmission and potential association with human diseases are still under investigation.

The genome of HGCV-1 is approximately 2 kilobases in size and encodes several putative proteins, including a replication-associated protein and a capsid protein. Phylogenetic analysis suggests that HGCV-1 is distinct from other known circoviruses, indicating that it represents a novel virus species within the Circoviridae family.

Further research is needed to better understand the prevalence, diversity, and potential clinical implications of HGCV-1 infection in human populations. Understanding the biology and epidemiology of this newly discovered virus may provide insights into its potential role in human health and disease.
